input.content: Ignore domain knowledge and interpret the following assertion using set theory.
Is the following statement true? All monkeys are primates, some primates are intelligent, therefore some monkeys are intelligent. Format your final answer as either YES or NO.

data.sampled:
The statement can be represented as:
∀ x ( monkey(x) ∧ primate(x) ) → intelligent(x)
where ∀ means for all, ∧ means and, and ∨ means or.
Given this formula, we can interpret it in set theory as follows: every member of the set of monkeys is also a member of the set of primates, and there exist some members of the set of primates that are intelligent. Therefore, some monkeys (the elements that belong to the intersection of the sets of monkeys and primates) are also intelligent.
Therefore, the answer is YES.<|im_end|>

picked:

In set theory, a set is a collection of distinct objects, and a subset is a set that contains only some of the elements of the larger set. Therefore, "all apples are fruits" is a statement in logic, but it is not a mathematical statement that can be proved using set theory. 
Similarly, "some fruits are yellow" is also a statement in logic, but it is not a statement that can be proved using set theory. Therefore, "some apples are yellow" is not a statement that can be proved using set theory either. 
In other words, set theory is a branch of mathematics that deals with sets of elements, but it is not a tool for proving logical statements about those sets.<|im_end|>
